docs.snippet: The foreign-language and short films are often the culprits keeping people from emerging victorious in their Oscar pools....
docs.lead_paragraph: Aside from the technical categories - sound editing and the like - foreign-language and short films are often the downfall of most people's Oscar pools. Well, the Bagger is looking out for you. Before you place your bets, we'll help you do a little self-education (or point you to others with the same impulse). At the In Contention blog, Kris Tapley breaks down the foreign-language films, which are somehow ripe for upset every year (last year's winner was the little-seen Japanese film "Departures").
docs.abstract: The foreign-language and short films are often the culprits keeping people from emerging victorious in their Oscar pools.

docs.snippet: With a quarter-moon curtain made of 100,000 Swarovski crystals, three revolving platforms, multiple rotating L.E.D. panels, architecture metal work and mirrors, the Oscar set is more complex than ever....
docs.lead_paragraph: Bigger, shinier and with more moving parts: those could be the key words for this year's Oscars. They certainly apply to the telecast's set, which was revealed on Wednesday by the designer, David Rockwell. With a quarter-moon curtain made of 100,000 Swarovski crystals, three revolving platforms, multiple rotating L.E.D. panels, architecture metal work and mirrors, the set is more complex than ever, according to the show's producers, Adam Shankman and Bill Mechanic. Mr. Rockwell, who also designed the stage last year, was inspired by his childhood in Mexico, as well "the optimism of modernism in L.A. and the heyday of Hollywood," he said, according to The Los Angeles Times. The design is meant to encompass the basic elements of moviemaking -- light and movement -- as well as frame the hosts, Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin, and involve the audience in the theater. But capturing it for the audience at home won't be easy.
docs.abstract: With a quarter-moon curtain made of 100,000 Swarovski crystals, three revolving platforms, multiple rotating L.E.D. panels, architecture metal work and mirrors, the Oscar set is more complex than ever.

docs.snippet: Echoing a lament long heard about the movie industry's poor treatment of wordsmiths, Walter Kirn, the author of the novel "Up in the Air," complains about not being invited to the Oscars....
docs.lead_paragraph: "Novelists are like oil in H'wood: they drill us, pipeline us, pump us and then burn us."
docs.abstract: Echoing a lament long heard about the movie industry's poor treatment of wordsmiths, Walter Kirn, the author of the novel "Up in the Air," complains about not being invited to the Oscars.

headline.main: The Writer's Sad Lot in Hollywood

docs.snippet: Robert Kenner, the director of "Food Inc.," finds himself bombarded with dinner invitations, though the hosts are scared about what to serve....
docs.lead_paragraph: What do you serve at a dinner party for "Food, Inc.," the Oscar-nominated documentary about the evils of agri-business? Especially when it's hosted by Martha Stewart? A healthy buffet and "eco-friendly" cocktails, apparently, along with pigs-in-blankets for the likes of the restaurateur Drew Nieporent, who turned up at the party at the Monkey Bar, along with the documentary filmmaker Albert Maysles and others on Tuesday night.
docs.abstract: Robert Kenner, the director of "Food Inc.," finds himself bombarded with dinner invitations, though the hosts are scared about what to serve.

headline.main: The Perils of Oscar Season Eating
